title: Awkward parse error for macro_rule repetition missing its `*`/`+`/`?`

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: <https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=99c47e5e030aa3460464df5c45097a9b>

```rust
macro_rules! checked_sum {
    ( $first:expr $(, $rest:expr ) $(,)? ) => {
        [$($rest),*].into_iter().try_fold($first, |a, b| a.checked_add(b))
    }
}
```

(where I forgot the `*` after the `)`)

The current output is:

```
error: expected one of: `*`, `+`, or `?`
 --> src/main.rs:2:37
  |
2 |     ( $first:expr $(, $rest:expr ) $(,)? ) => {
  |                                     ^^^

error: `$first:expr` may be followed by `?`, which is not allowed for `expr` fragments
 --> src/main.rs:2:40
  |
2 |     ( $first:expr $(, $rest:expr ) $(,)? ) => {
  |                                        ^ not allowed after `expr` fragments
  |
  = note: allowed there are: `=>`, `,` or `;`

error: `$rest:expr` is followed by `?`, which is not allowed for `expr` fragments
 --> src/main.rs:2:40
  |
2 |     ( $first:expr $(, $rest:expr ) $(,)? ) => {
  |                                        ^ not allowed after `expr` fragments
  |
  = note: allowed there are: `=>`, `,` or `;`

error: could not compile `playground` due to 3 previous errors
```

Because that error `^^^`'d the `(,)` part, I thought I got the "optional trailing comma" part wrong, and ended up looking that up again before realizing that it wasn't the problem at all.

(Would be nice if the grammar here made it easier to resync, but maybe whitespace can help hint.  Or hopefully most people aren't doing `$(...)$+`...)


<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

```
  |
2 |     ( $first:expr $(, $rest:expr ) $(,)? ) => {
  |                                  ^ help: did you forget a repetition operator?
```
